Topic: Draw animals in their habitats with labels (e.g., fish in water).
CAN: The student might draw a few animals and plants without labels, displaying some awareness of different living things. (e.g., drawing shapes that vaguely resemble animals like fish or trees but not clearly identifiable)
The student may include a simple representation of a habitat, such as a blue area that could represent water or a patch of green for grass, without specific labels.
CANNOT: The student is unlikely to effectively label animals, plants, or habitats consistently. (student may not know names or forget to label)
The student does not show or label what each plant and animal needs to survive, such as water, air, or sunlight. (student doesn’t understand these needs)
The student is unable to illustrate how living things and their habitats work together as a system. (student doesn’t grasp interactions)
The student does not demonstrate connections between animals or plants and the resources they use in their drawings. (e.g., no link between fish and water)
The student fails to show patterns like plants needing sunlight; they may place a plant inside a water body and label it incorrectly. (student has misconceptions about plant needs)
